posts.cooked:
We have a new issue with our swerve drive after REV changed how you configure SparkMaxes, along with whatever other changes happened between them and WPILib in the 2025 update. The issue we are having is that the front two work fine, but the back two only work fine when the robot is not supposed to be turning. When it’s turning, the back wheels are off by 90 degrees. I have tried about 6 different ways of optimizing the wheel turning (so they never turn farther than 90 degrees). My only current theory is that it’s a wiring issue, except all the wiring is fine. Any and all help and/or ideas would be appreciated. Here’s the code:

GitHub - BoyneCityBlaze4377/SWERVEDRIVE Contribute to BoyneCityBlaze4377/SWERVEDRIVE development by creating an account on GitHub.

Contribute to BoyneCityBlaze4377/SWERVEDRIVE development by creating an account on GitHub.

p.s. everything worked fine the day before the update

I’ve figured out that for some reason the built-in encoders on the SparkMaxes and the Absolute Encoders are not syncing for those two modules. The built-in encoders think they have reached their destination at a different point from where the absolute encoders do. I have reset the encoders multiple times and replaced both Motors and their Motor Controllers

posts.name: Tanya Drake
posts.cooked: We are also having trouble - did you find a solution or something specific we should be looking for with the update?

posts.name: Tanya Drake
posts.cooked: We are running a Mk4i and Neos/spark max with cancoders . We are trying to run it on last year’s robot and it was working before the update.

We do not have a solution yet and have heard from other teams in our area that they are having the same problem. We believe that the problem might be the line of code that sets the NEOs’ built-in encoders (called relative encoders) value equal to the value given by the absolute encoders. After further testing, I am starting to doubt this but have no better lead I also have no experience with CANcoders so I don’t know that I can help you specifically. But I will post our solution once we have one

posts.name: Bryson Smith
posts.cooked: My team has had something like this problem this season. I am still working through the problem somewhat, so take this for what it is worth. I believe that cancoders are resetting to zero when they are created in code regardless of the offset created in the phoenix tuner application. I solved this by putting the offsets into the code itself and resetting to the offset when constructing the cancoder. Our code is in python and can be found here: GitHub - BrysonSmith15/9445SwerveTemplatePy: The python3 swerve template for team 9445 I hope that this can help!

link_counts.title: GitHub - BrysonSmith15/9445SwerveTemplatePy: The python3 swerve template for team 9445

posts.name: Datis Reyhani
posts.cooked:
This is a long shot, but have you checked that the firmware on all of your spark maxes is updated to the latest 2025 version? That could be causing the issue, since it caused a similar problem for us. You can update all of them via the Hardware Client.

Hope this helps!
